greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(0) = 1, a(2n+1) = a(n), a(2n) = a(n) + a(n-1) + ... + a(n-2^m) + ... where a(n) = 0 for n < 0.
comment: Conjecture: all a(n) are even except a(2^k-1) = 1. Also a(2^k-2) = 2^(k-1). [For proof see link.]
a(n) is the number of ways of writing n as a sum of powers of 2, where each power appears p times, with p itself a power of 2.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
Peter Luschny, Rational Trees and Binary Partitions.
formula: G.f.: Product_{k>=0} (1 + Sum_{j>=0} x^(2^(k+j)). [Corrected by Herbert S. Wilf, May 31 2006]
example: The sequence splits into rows of length 2^k:
The first few partitions counted are (compare with the list in A174980):
maple: local IndexSet, k; IndexSet := proc(n) local i, j, z;
i := iquo(n,2); j := i; if odd::n then i := i-1; z := 1;
while 0 <= i do j := j,i; i := i-z; z := z+z od fi; j end:
if n < 2 then 1 else add(A086449(k),k=IndexSet(n)) fi end:
a:= proc(n) option remember; local r; `if`(n=0, 1,
program: (MAGMA) m:=80; R<x>:=PowerSeriesRing(Integers(), m); Coefficients(R!( (&*[1 + (&+[x^(2^(k+j)): j in [0..m/4]]): k in [0..m/4]]) )); // _G. C. Greubel_, Feb 11 2019
results.author: _Ralf Stephan_, Jul 20 2003
